awd_titl_txt: Cyber-Physical Systems Virtual Organization: Active Resources
awd_abstract_narration:
The Cyber-Physical Systems Virtual Organization (CPS-VO) was founded by NSF in 2010 to: (i)facilitate and foster interaction and exchanges among CPS PIs and their teams; (ii) enable sharing of artifacts and knowledge generated by the projects with the broader engineering and scientific communities; and (iii) facilitate and foster collaboration and information exchange between CPS researchers and industry. During the last five years, the CPS-VO has become the focal point of the CPS community in the US and it has played a significant role in catalyzing CPS research world-wide. The CPS-VO Portal serves as a central information repository and as a collaboration platform for the rapidly growing research community. It is the home for ~150 special interest groups, reaches over 8,000 members, and includes over 12,000 webpages and over 18,000 files capturing the first 8 years of CPS history. This proposal looks to envision how the CPS-VO will be transformed over the next years into an resource which becomes a "destination for doing" rather than a repository and collaboration capability. 

In this proposal we address the next phase of development of the CPS-VO: (1) changing the Portal from being a passive information 
repository and collaboration platform to becoming an active resource as research tool for CPS, (2) serving as an integration platform for open source CPS tools and models emerging from the research community and (3) making the Portal an active resource for CPS education. Active Resources encapsulate the new capabilities of the CPS-VO. Research teams may contribute to Active Resources on three different levels: (a) end-to-end design and simulation tool chains and test beds including model repositories, tools and web-based user interfaces to access resources, (b) individual tools that can be integrated into design flows, and (c) models and code integrated into open repositories. The proposal will spur CPS community growth through conducting series of student competitions to be held in the first two years building on unmanned air vehicle design studio from UPenn that will allow students and researchers to study the physical design, dynamics and control of quad rotors, a multi-model simulation system from Vanderbilt facilitating the virtual integration  of embedded software for control, estimation, planning, and coordinated, dynamic flight of multiple micro air vehicles. In addition, the CPS VO will extend outreach to the community to identify new and emerging VO needs and provide enhanced user experience through redesign of the user facing portal and integration of new information management technologies.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The Cyber-Physical Systems Virtual Organization (http://cps-vo.org) was conceived by Vanderbilt University in 2009 to address NSF?s objectives of creating a cross-disciplinary, interagency CPS initiative and building a strong CPS research community in the U.S. and internationally. Vanderbilt?s charge was to build an online platform to:

  • facilitate and foster interaction and exchanges among CPS PIs and their teams

  • enable sharing of artifacts and knowledge generated by these research projects with the broader engineering and scientific communities

  • facilitate and foster collaboration and information exchange between CPS researchers and industry

Having successfully accomplished these goals to satisfy the NSF charge of creating an online CPS research and education community through the initial Virtual Organization for Cyber-Physical Research (VO-CyPhER) award (NSF-0931632, 2009-2015), Vanderbilt proposed to scale up the research that would be required to address the complexities for enabling the execution of higher levels of cross-disciplinary work, tighter interaction between academic and industry research, and transformation in education with the help of the platform.

Vanderbilt identified that the critical missing link is a fundamentally new capability enabling experts to make their models, methods, and tools available for active exploration by other researchers and potential users. NSF awarded a second grant through the CPS Active Resources award (NSF 1521617, 2015-2021) to Vanderbilt with the central objective of transforming the platform from being a passive information repository to becoming an active resource that provides access to tools and methods emerging from CPS research. This change required making the Portal an integration platform for open-source CPS tools and models. In essence, the vision is for researchers to ?actively explore and conduct'' research as opposed to just ?finding information? on the platform. It was determined that the proposed transformation of the CPS-VO Portal into an active research and education resource was a significant undertaking that required deep architectural changes, new services, and significant infrastructure resources. To achieve this approach, Vanderbilt employed expertise from four additional institutions ? the University of Pennsylvania, the University of Arizona, Arizona State University, and UCLA ? to collaboratively engage in what would be called the CPS-VO Active Resources phase 2 of the CPS VO project. Together, the five institutions would conduct distinct aspects of the research to address the following three major goals:

 

  • make the CPS-VO an active resource "for finding, trying, validating and transitioning research artifacts" in addition to a repository and collaboration capability (Vanderbilt and UCLA)

  • create a light-weight integration platform for open-source CPS tools and models emerging from the research community (Vanderbilt, University of Pennsylvania and the University of Arizona)

  • make the Portal an active resource for CPS education as a platform for student competitions. (Vanderbilt, University of Pennsylvania, The University of Arizona, and Arizona State)

The core hypothesis of the project was that availability of models and tools produced by and accessible for the research community, and integration platforms that allow experts to develop and test design flows would accelerate the progress in CPS research, education and transitioning. To date, the following have been accomplished on the CPS VO platform:

  • Over 50 verification tools have been logged in the platform?s Tools repository (over 50 verification tools)

  • Types of integrated tools on the platform include prototypes and education materials (integration prototype, education material, prototypes)

  • Over 10 Design Studio prototypes with pre-integrated services and education material have been archived

With the success of the first two CPS VO awards, a third follow-on grant -- The Cyber-Physical Systems Virtual Organization: CPS Community and the Data Revolution (NSF 2151500, 2021-2026) --was awarded to Vanderbilt by NSF in 2021. The goals are to continue to support and renew the CPS-VO infrastructure, while embracing the data revolution which entails expanding the CPS-VO's capacity to disseminate and collect data, models, and results from existing CPS PIs? research projects thus making their research more readily accessible to others, as well as providing a means by which issues of repeatability and replicability can be demonstrated.


Last Modified: 01/28/2023
Modified by: Janos Sztipanovits

Image
  • Architecture comparison of the CPS-VO to previous iterations. (Left) Previous architecture redi- rected from the top level, but shared all modules and themes. (Right) New architecture that streamlines custom site development and can decouple modules and site themes for improved researcher/user expe-

por.por_txt_cntn:
The Cyber-Physical Systems Virtual Organization (http://cps-vo.org) was conceived by Vanderbilt University in 2009 to address NSF?s objectives of creating a cross-disciplinary, interagency CPS initiative and building a strong CPS research community in the U.S. and internationally. Vanderbilt?s charge was to build an online platform to:


facilitate and foster interaction and exchanges among CPS PIs and their teams


enable sharing of artifacts and knowledge generated by these research projects with the broader engineering and scientific communities


facilitate and foster collaboration and information exchange between CPS researchers and industry


Having successfully accomplished these goals to satisfy the NSF charge of creating an online CPS research and education community through the initial Virtual Organization for Cyber-Physical Research (VO-CyPhER) award (NSF-0931632, 2009-2015), Vanderbilt proposed to scale up the research that would be required to address the complexities for enabling the execution of higher levels of cross-disciplinary work, tighter interaction between academic and industry research, and transformation in education with the help of the platform.
Vanderbilt identified that the critical missing link is a fundamentally new capability enabling experts to make their models, methods, and tools available for active exploration by other researchers and potential users. NSF awarded a second grant through the CPS Active Resources award (NSF 1521617, 2015-2021) to Vanderbilt with the central objective of transforming the platform from being a passive information repository to becoming an active resource that provides access to tools and methods emerging from CPS research. This change required making the Portal an integration platform for open-source CPS tools and models. In essence, the vision is for researchers to ?actively explore and conduct'' research as opposed to just ?finding information? on the platform. It was determined that the proposed transformation of the CPS-VO Portal into an active research and education resource was a significant undertaking that required deep architectural changes, new services, and significant infrastructure resources. To achieve this approach, Vanderbilt employed expertise from four additional institutions ? the University of Pennsylvania, the University of Arizona, Arizona State University, and UCLA ? to collaboratively engage in what would be called the CPS-VO Active Resources phase 2 of the CPS VO project. Together, the five institutions would conduct distinct aspects of the research to address the following three major goals:
 

make the CPS-VO an active resource "for finding, trying, validating and transitioning research artifacts" in addition to a repository and collaboration capability (Vanderbilt and UCLA)

create a light-weight integration platform for open-source CPS tools and models emerging from the research community (Vanderbilt, University of Pennsylvania and the University of Arizona)


make the Portal an active resource for CPS education as a platform for student competitions. (Vanderbilt, University of Pennsylvania, The University of Arizona, and Arizona State)


The core hypothesis of the project was that availability of models and tools produced by and accessible for the research community, and integration platforms that allow experts to develop and test design flows would accelerate the progress in CPS research, education and transitioning. To date, the following have been accomplished on the CPS VO platform:


Over 50 verification tools have been logged in the platform?s Tools repository (over 50 verification tools)


Types of integrated tools on the platform include prototypes and education materials (integration prototype, education material, prototypes)


Over 10 Design Studio prototypes with pre-integrated services and education material have been archived



With the success of the first two CPS VO awards, a third follow-on grant -- The Cyber-Physical Systems Virtual Organization: CPS Community and the Data Revolution (NSF 2151500, 2021-2026) --was awarded to Vanderbilt by NSF in 2021. The goals are to continue to support and renew the CPS-VO infrastructure, while embracing the data revolution which entails expanding the CPS-VO's capacity to disseminate and collect data, models, and results from existing CPS PIs? research projects thus making their research more readily accessible to others, as well as providing a means by which issues of repeatability and replicability can be demonstrated.
